College of New Materials and Chemical Engineering Beijing Institute of Petrochemical Technology Beijing 102617 China Catalytic oxidation is an effective way for toluene-bearing VOCs removal. A series of Co-grafted dendritic mesoporous silica nanospheres (Co-DMSNs-f) were synthesized by the controlled grafting method. The catalysts show superior micro-structure, high dispersion of CoOx species and proper metal-support interaction. For comparison, corresponding DMSNs-supported CoOx samples were prepared by impregnation method. Co-grafted DMSNs samples yield better structure stability. For the Co-grafted DMSNs, moisture is involved in the activation of O2 and exhibits a short and reversible negative effect on catalytic activity. The influence of Pd-modification on the Co-containing catalysts was also investigated and the introduction of Pd can markedly enhance the catalytic performance. The supported catalysts generate proper CoOx-SiO2 and Pd-CoOx interactions. The Pd-CoOx interface can further influence the synergistic effect in oxygen activation and toluene adsorption. The tunable CoOx-support and Pd-CoOx interactions play an important role in the toluene oxidation. Graphical abstracts Image, graphical abstract Keywords Dendritic mesoporous silica nanosphere Surface functionalization Toluene-bearing VOC Catalytic oxidation Pd-CoOx interactions 1 Introduction Increasing volatile organic compounds (VOCs) emission to the atmosphere generates the environmental pollution and serious threat to human health [1,2]. Benzene, toluene and chlorobenzene are typical components of aromatic VOCs [3]. Toluene is widely used in petrochemical, organic chemical, pharmaceutical, dye and other fields. It is necessary to reduce toluene emissions to meet human health and environmental standards. A number of technologies are available to control VOCs emissions, such as adsorption, combustion, photocatalytic oxidation and catalytic oxidation [4–6]. Catalytic oxidation has been regarded as one of the most promising methods to eliminate VOCs due to its high efficiency, low cost and secondary pollution free [6,7]. The crucial issue is the development of catalysts with high activity and stability. Generally, the main catalysts for VOCs oxidation are single and composite transition metal oxides [6,8,9] and supported noble metal or transition metal oxide [10–12]. Transition metal oxides, such as Co3O4 [13,14] and MnO2 [1], usually contain the lattice defects, i.e., oxygen vacancies in various oxidation states [15]. The redox cycle can promote the adsorption and activation of O2 and toluene, and those oxides show good catalytic activity in toluene oxidation. In recent years, cobalt oxides with different morphologies, such as nanowires [16], nanorods [17], nanotubes [18], bamboo leaf-like [19], urchins-like [14] and octahedron [20], were successfully synthesized and show excellent catalytic performance in toluene oxidation. Bai et al. prepared the Co3O4 catalyst by the hydrothermal method with cetyltrimethylammonium bromide as a surfactant [16], which displays a porous nanowire-like morphology and shows excellent activity in catalytic oxidation of toluene. This is associated with the high surface Co2+/Co3+ molar ratio, abundant surface adsorption oxygen and good low-temperature reducibility. The addition of palladium can usually generate the synergistic effect between the Pd-Co bimetal and improve the low-temperature activity of cobalt-based catalysts. Xie et al. reported that the Pd/meso-CoO catalyst shows excellent catalytic performance in o-xylene combustion [21], which can be associated with the highly active Pd-CoO interface with high ability of oxygen activation and o-xylene adsorption. Zhao et al. found that the chemical state of palladium plays an important role in the catalytic oxidation of VOCs [22]. Metallic Pd can promote the activation of oxygen into active adsorbed oxygen (Oads) species, and exhibits high catalytic activity in degrading benzene. Supported catalysts are an important type of catalyst system, and the common supports mainly include oxides, composite oxides and molecular sieves. The support can regulate the structure, improve the dispersity of active metal and the stability, and generate proper interaction or synergistic effect [23]. Ji et al. synthesized the three-dimensionally ordered macroporous (3DOM) Co3O4 and mixed oxides catalysts [24]. The results show that the 3DOM catalysts exhibit better catalytic activity than the bulk Co3O4, which is closely related to the reactive oxygen species, low-temperature reducibility and synergistic effect between Co3O4 and 3DOM-mixed oxides. Especially, a variety of mesoporous silica materials with high surface area, regular mesostructure, high stability and easy functionalization are preferred supports for catalyst preparation. During the preparation of Co/MCM-41 and Co/SBA-15 catalysts, Szegedi et al. found that the pH of impregnation solution can affect the surface charge of mesoporous support and the interaction between cobalt oxides and support [25]. Various cobalt oxides such as Co3O4, Co2+ or Co-silicate are formed, and Co3O4 may be more suitable for the oxidation of toluene than other species. Recently, a novel dendritic mesoporous silica nanosphere (DMSNs) material with unique central radial pore structure has been reported in the literature [26–28], which is expected to become a new type of catalyst carrier. It is superior to common mesoporous silica such as HMS, MCM-41 and SBA-15 due to the large pore entrance and uniform monodispersed nanoparticle structure, which is hardly blocked and provides good accessibility of active sites and rapid diffusion of reactants [29]. Besides, the DMSNs materials are convenient and fast to be synthesized within only several hours. This nanomaterial can further be functionalized and modified by doping with active heterogeneous elements. Herein, DMSNs were used as the support to prepare the cobalt-containing DMSNs catalysts with various levels of cobalt oxide loadings by grafting and impregnation method, separately. The influence of Pd-modification on the Co-containing catalysts was then investigated. The physicochemical properties and microstructures of all the catalysts, such as the textural properties, surface composition, crystal phase, coordination geometry, redox ability and oxygen activation ability, were characterized by a variety of techniques. The catalytic performance and stability of catalysts in the oxidation of toluene were also comparatively studied. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Preparation of dendritic mesoporous silica nanospheres (DMSNs) DMSNs were obtained via typical hydrothermal synthesis method. At first, 0.41 g of triethanolamine (TEA) was added to 150 ml of water at 80 °C under magnetic stirring for 0.5 h. Then 2.28 g Cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) and 1.01 g Sodium salicylate (NaSal) were added into the above solution and stirred for another 1 h. Afterwards, 22.43 g of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) was added to the water-TEA-CTAB-NaSal solution with stirring for 2 h. The mixed solution was transferred into a teflon autoclave at 80 °C for 4 h under static hydrothermal condition before cooled to room temperature. The precipitated product was filtered and washed thoroughly with distilled water, and dried at 80 °C for 12 h. Finally, the powders were put into a crucible and calcined in air at 550 °C for 6 h with a ramp of 1 °C/min from ambient to 550 °C. The dendritic mesoporous silica nanospheres materials were obtained and denoted as DMSNs 2.1.2 Surface functionalization of DMSNs The DMSNs materials were functionalized using the 3-Aminopropyl triethoxysilane (APTES) and terminal amine group was introduced onto the DMSNs surface. In a sealed flask equipped with reflux condenser and water bath, 2 g of as-synthesized DMSNs and 1.48 g of APTES were added into 200 ml ethanol, and then stirred at 80 °C for 12 h. After reaction, the surface functionalized DMSNs were cooled to room temperature, and washed with ethanol and deionized water several times in a centrifuge at 9000 rpm/min to remove residual APTES. Subsequently, the APTES modified DMSNs were dried overnight at 60 °C. The obtained surface functionalized DMSNs were denoted as DMSNs-f. 2.1.3 Preparation of Co-DMSNs-f catalyst First, 2 g APTES functionalized DMSNs material was dispersed in 200 ml deionized water. Then, a required concentration of cobalt (II) chloride hexahydrate (CoCl2•6H2O) aqueous solution stabilized with 0.30 g of sodium citrate dihydrate (Na3C6H5O7•2H2O) were added. The suspension was then sealed and stirred at 600 rpm/min for 12 h. The CoCl2 concentration varied from 1 mM to 10 mM to obtain samples with different Co contents. The resulted precipitate was centrifuged, washed, dried at 60 °C and calcined at 400 °C for 6 h with a ramp of 1 °C/min. The prepared catalyst was denoted as xCo-DMSNs-f, x denotes Co2+ concentration during synthetic process. The final Co content in the samples was determined by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) measurement. 2.1.4 Preparation of Co-supported DMSNs (Co/DMSNs) and Pd-supported Co-containing DMSNs (PdCo-DMSNs-f and PdCo/DMSNs) catalysts Co/DMSNs were prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method. A required amount of cobalt chloride was dissolved in deionized water and the resulting solution was added dropwise onto the DMSNs, while stirring with a glass rod. The impregnated samples were treated under ultrasound for 0.5 h and dried at 60 °C for 12 h. Then the powders were calcined at 400 °C for 6 h with a ramp of 1 °C/min to obtain the Co/DMSNs samples. By changing the amount of cobalt chloride, the catalysts with Co loadings of 1.7, 3, 10 and 30% were obtained. PdCo-DMSNs-f and PdCo/DMSNs samples were prepared by the same method as above, using Co-DMSNs-f or Co/DMSNs as the support materials. Predesigned amount of tetrachloropalladium acid (H2PdCl4, 0.1 mol/L) solution and deionized water were mixed to obtain 5 mL impregnation solution and ultrasonicated for 15 min. The solution was added dropwise to Co-containing DMSNs powder. The sample was treated under ultrasound for 0.5 h and in a vacuum oven at 80 °C for 12 h, before calcined in flowing N2 (100 mL/min) at 550 °C for 3 h. By changing the concentration of H2PdCl4 solution, the catalysts with Pd loadings of 0.5, 1, 2 and 3% were obtained. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) of catalysts was performed on the Shimadzu XRD-7000 diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα source (λ = 1.5418 Å) at 40 kV and 30 mA. The samples were scanned from 2θ = 10 to 80° with a scanning rate of 4°/min. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, QUANTE 400F) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2010) were used for the examination of morphology. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms were measured with the BELSORP-max apparatus at -196 °C. Before analysis, the samples were degassed at 200 °C for 4 h under vacuum conditions. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was performed on a BELCAT-B automatic temperature-programmed chemical adsorption instrument equipped with a TCD detector. 50 mg of sample was placed in the quartz tube and pretreated in high purity Ar (30 mL/min) at 300 °C for 1 h before cooled to 50 °C. The sample was reduced in a flow of 10% H2/Ar atmosphere from 50 to 900 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The amount of H2 consumption was quantified using CuO as internal standard. O2 temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD) was measured on the same device as H2-TPR. 50 mg of the sample was pretreated with N2 (30 mL/min) at 300 °C for 1 h. The sample was cooled to room temperature, adsorbed in O2 (40 mL/min) for 1 h, and then purged with He (30 mL/min) for 1 h to remove the residual O2 in the system. The sample was heated from room temperature to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Shimadzu Kratos AXIS Ultra DLD X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to detect the surface elemental composition and chemical state of sample. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) was used to determine the Co and Pd loading on Agilent 725 equipment. 2.3 Catalytic activity evaluation The catalytic oxidation of toluene was performed in a continuous flow micro-reactor at atmospheric pressure. Typically, 0.2 g of catalyst with 40–60 mesh was packed in the middle of the tubular quartz-reactor (id = 6 mm). The mixed reactants were 50 ppm toluene, 20.0 vol% O2 in balance N2 with a total flow of 50 mL/min. Before reaction, the mixed gas was continuously passed into the empty tube to obtain the initial concentration. Then, the catalyst was installed in the quartz-reactor with quartz wool, and the toluene conversion was calculated under a given temperature after 0.5 h of stabilization. The gas mixture after reaction was separated with a TM-15 capillary column and analyzed by an online GC-7900 gas chromatograph with FID. The conversion (X%) of toluene was calculated based on the following equations: X % = 100 % × ( C in − C out ) / C in where Cin and Cout represent the toluene concentrations at the inlet and outlet of the reactor, respectively. The temperatures (T10, T50, and T90) at 10, 50 and 90% toluene conversion are used to evaluate the catalytic activity of samples. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the Co-DMSNs-f and Co/DMSNs catalysts 3.1.1 Physical properties of catalysts SEM and TEM were used to evaluate the microscopic morphology and dispersibility of cobalt oxide in the Co-DMSNs-f and Co/DMSNs samples. It can be seen in Fig. 1 (a–f) that the Co-DMSNs-f samples present the structure of dendritic nanospheres and exhibit a diameter of ∼280 nm. As the TEM images shown in Fig. 1(g–i), the nanosphere has a center-radial pore structure and the surfaces are wrinkled sheets of silica which form the large radial pore opening of about 35 nm. This is consistent with the result of nitrogen adsorption-desorption. With increasing cobalt content, the morphology structure of Co-DMSNs-f samples is principally maintained, but part of wrinkled surface is affected. Some uniform nanospheres change from monodispersed particles to cross-linked clusters. In addition, no obvious large cobalt oxide particles are observed, which is in agreement with the XRD results, indicating that CoOx species exist in the form of tiny nanoparticles or highly dispersed species. Fig. 1(j) shows SEM-EDS elemental analysis data of the 3Co-DMSNs-f sample. The mass fraction of cobalt is about 1.7%, which is consistent with ICP result. It suggests that Co species are highly dispersed on the DMSNs support. The SEM and TEM images of the Co/DMSNs samples synthesized by the incipient wetness impregnation method are shown in Fig. S1. The Co/DMSNs samples also show the morphological structure of dendritic mesoporous nanospheres. For the sample with low cobalt loading, the cobalt oxides are uniformly dispersed on the surface of nanospheres. This indicates that the center-radial mesoporous structure can effectively promote the dispersion of cobalt species and inhibit the blocking of mesopores. Even though the Co loading increases to 10%, only some tiny CoOx nanoparticles are formed on the surface of catalyst as shown in Fig. S1(g, h). When the Co loading reaches as high as 30%, some uniform nanospheres change from the monodispersed particles to the interlinked clusters. The wrinkled surface and pore are filled by the bulk cobalt oxides. Overall, the dendritic mesoporous structure is beneficial to promoting the dispersion of Co species and shows good nanostructure stability. Fig. 2 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig. 2a) and pore size distribution diagrams (Fig. 2b) of the Co-DMSNs-f and Co/DMSNs samples. Type IV adsorption-desorption isotherms with H3 hysteresis loop are observed for all the samples, suggesting that samples are typical ordered mesoporous materials [30]. The peak height and width in the pore size distribution diagrams represent the number and uniformity of pores, respectively. As shown in Fig. 2b, the Co loading has no remarkable effect on the pore size distribution of catalysts. The synthesized catalysts maintain the mesoporous stucture and the pore size is mainly distributed between 5 and 60 nm with two obvious peaks at ∼25 nm and ∼35 nm. For the Co-DMSNs-f samples, the pore-size distribution becomes dispersive gradually and more small mesopores are formed with increasing Co loading. The Co/DMSNs samples show a decreasing tendency of pore size distributed between 5 and 20 nm. This can attribute to the impregnation process in which the small mesopore is blocked by the bulk cobalt oxides gradually. Textural properties including surface area, average pore diameter and total pore volume of Co-DMSNs-f and Co/DMSNs catalysts are summarized in Table 1 . It is obvious that the textural properties of catalysts maintain almost the same parameters as the DMSNs. For the Co-DMSNs-f catalysts, when the cobalt concentration increases from 0.5 to 10 mM, the specific surface area raries from 380 to 399 m2/g, which is slightly lower than 436 m2/g of DMSNs carrier. The pore size and pore volume also change slightly. It can be concluded that the introduction of Co have no significant effects on the pore structure of Co-DMSNs-f samples. For the Co/DMSNs samples, as the Co content increases from 1.7 to 10%, the specific surface area and pore volume only decrease from 414 to 352 m2/g and from 1.48 to 1.47 cm3/g, respectively. However, when the cobalt loading exceeds 10%, the surface area and pore volume are significantly reduced. Excessive Co loading results that the surface wrinkles or pores of samples are gradually filled, and shows an obvious drop in the specific surface area and pore volume. However, the specific surface area decreases relatively slowly, compared with the mesoporous materials with smaller mesoporous channels, such as MCM-41and SBA-15 [25,31]. The average pore sizes of Co-DMSNs-f and Co/DMSNs samples are in the range of 21–28 nm, as shown in Table 1. This is consistent with the peaks of pore size distribution. The special radial pore structure of DMSNs materials is conducive to the dispersion of active species and not easy to cause pore blockage, which can maintain the original ordered mesoporous structure of carrier. Therefore, the larger specific surface area and pore size of Co-DMSNs-f and Co/DMSNs catalysts can not only provide a high accessible area, but also promote the transfer of reactants and products in the pore for toluene oxidation reaction. Fig. 3 depicts the XRD patterns of Co-DMSNs-f and Co/DMSNs catalysts. The broad peak in the range of 18–30° is attributed to the characteristic diffraction peak of amorphous SiO2. For the Co-DMSNs-f samples synthesized by the grafting method, no significant cobalt oxide peaks are observed although the concentration of Co increases from 0.5 to 10 mM. It suggests that CoOx species are highly dispersed on the DMSNs and do not aggregate to form relatively large particles. For the Co/DMSNs prepared by impregnation method, the characteristic diffraction peaks of the spinel structures of Co3O4 (PDF#42-1467) are clearly observed [32]. In addition, the peak intensity gradually grows with increasing Co loading, suggesting that the crystallinity of Co3O4 phase in Co/DMSNs increases. It also shows that some new peaks appear in the Co/DMSNs with high Co loading, which are belong to CoCl2·6H2O (PDF#29-0466). It indicates that excessive CoCl2 on the DMSNs support cannot be completely oxidized to Co oxides at a relatively low calcination temperature. XRD results demonstrate that the Co-DMSNs-f catalysts synthesized by the grafting method have a higher dispersion of cobalt oxide species than the Co/DMSNs catalysts synthesized by the impregnation method. 3.1.2 Chemical properties of catalysts The reducibility of the Co-DMSNs-f and Co/DMSNs catalysts were further characterized by H2-TPR, and the results are presented in Fig. 4 . According to the literature [18], the CoOx species generally exhibit two reduction processes assigned to the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ and Co2+ to Co0. It can be observed that Co-DMSNs-f and Co/DMSNs catalysts present different reduction peaks in the temperature range of 200–850 °C. For the Co-DMSNs-f samples, the reduction peaks show relatively weak intensity at high temperature. The peaks between 500 and 850 °C can be attributed to the reduction of Co2+ to Co0 species with strong metal-support interaction. It may be due to the formation of cobalt silicate species during the calcination process and difficult to reduce [33].The high temperature reduction peak implies that Co2+ species are highly dispersed on the surface and/or in the framework of DMSNs [34,35]. The Co-DMSNs-f samples also show a broad reduction process, resulting from the different coordination environment of CoOx species. The Co-DMSNs-f samples with low actual Co content show very low and broad reduction peaks, suggesting that the CoOx species in the Co-DMSNs-f samples are almost unreduceable in this temperature range, and the negligible amounts of H2 consumption of Co-DMSNs-f samples also verify it. For the Co/DMSNs sample with low loading (1.7%), two reduction peaks are found at the temperatures of 312 and 354 °C, which are the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and the subsequent reduction to metallic cobalt [34]. The broad reduction peak at 500–700 °C should be ascribed to high dispersed Co2+ species strongly interacting with the support. When the Co loading increases to 10%, an obvious sharp peak appears between 460 and 480 °C, which is attributed to the reduction process of homogeneous tiny CoOx nanoparticles [36]. However, the reduction peaks of 30%Co/DMSNs sample shows an overlapped peak, which can be attributed to the reduction of bulk Co3O4. Therefore, the excessive cobalt loading gradually block the mesopores to generate bulk cobalt oxide, resulting in the reduction process similar to bulk cobalt oxide [37]. Furthermore, the amounts of H2 consumption were quantified over Co/DMSNs samples as shown in Table 1. It can be seen that the Co/DMSNs samples with less than 10% Co content show relatively large amounts of H2 consumption proportional to the Co content. However, the molar mass of H2 consumption is obviously larger than the corresponding Co molar mass of samples. It indicates that the abundant surface oxygen species should contribute to the H2 consumption. But the amount of H2 consumption over 30%Co/DMSNs decreases significantly based on the Co content that may be due to an appreciable amount of Co species in the form of CoCl2 species. The adsorption performance of oxygen molecule plays an important role in catalytic oxidation of toluene. Therefore, the O2-TPD experiment was performed to obtain information about the adsorbed oxygen species of Co-DMSNs-f and Co/DMSNs samples. Generally, there are four different types of desorption peaks for the cobalt oxides: oxygen vacancies (Ov) in adsorbed molecular oxygen species, oxygen ions adsorbed on the surface (Oads), surface lattice oxygen (Olatt, s) and lattice oxygen (Olatt,b) in the bulk phase [18,38]. During the O2-TPD process, the sequence of desorption follows Ov > Oads > Olatt,s > Olatt,b [18]. As shown in Fig. 5 , the desorption peaks are roughly divided into four temperature ranges: 50–120 °C, 120–450 °C, 450–700 °C and >700 °C, corresponding to oxygen vacancies, surface adsorption oxygen, the surface lattice oxygen and lattice oxygen of bulk phase, respectively. The Co-DMSNs-f samples display a larger peak at ca. 100 °C, corresponding to the molecular oxygen desorbed from oxygen vacancy of catalysts. Besides, it appears a new peak at 400–750 °C assigned to the surface lattice oxygen O2−, which is related to the highly dispersed CoOx species. The 3Co-DMSNs-f sample shows a very broad desorption interval at 200–750 °C including the surface adsorbed O− and lattice oxygen O2− species. The integral areas of oxygen desorption peaks at 100–200 °C and 200–750 °C are quantified as shown in Fig. S2. The amount of desorbed molecular oxygen at ca. 100 °C is increasing and then changes little when the Co content is greater than 1 mM. However, 3Co-DMSNs-f sample shows much larger area of the desorption peak at 200–750 °C than other samples. These results reveal that the great mobility of oxygen species is enhanced for the 3Co-DMSNs-f sample. The surface of 3Co-DMSNs-f sample shows a high concentration of Co2+ ions that play a key role in the oxygen adsorption and formation of active oxygen species in toluene oxidation reaction. The Co/DMSNs catalysts also exhibit a broad peak in the middle temperature range but with very low intensity. The amount and mobility of active oxygen species are insufficient. Moreover, the S10% sample appears a peak at 763 °C that can be attributed to the desorption of bulk lattice oxygen, suggesting the existence of cobalt oxide nanoparticles in the supported samples (S10%). The S30% sample shows a large peak at 701 °C that can be attributed to the thermal decomposition of CoCl2 species. 3.1.3 Local structure and environment of catalysts XPS measurement was employed to investigate the surface chemical state of the Co-DMSNs-f and Co/DMSNs catalysts, and the results are summarized in Fig. 6 . The XPS spectra of Co 2p consist of doublet characteristic peaks, attributed to Co 2p3/2 at 781.9 eV and Co 2p1/2 at 798 eV. An interval of ∼16 eV between the Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 is reported to be due to the existence of silicon-cobalt structure in the silica matrix [39]. The binding energy exceeding 782.0 eV is due to the Co2+ ions embedded within DMSNs [40]. Moreover, the binding energy value of Co2p3/2 at 781.9 eV can be assigned to the highly dispersed Co2+ species and the fitting peak at 779.7 eV to surface Co3+ species [41,42]. Besides, the presence of satellite peak at 786.3 eV shows the interaction between cobalt oxide and carrier [40]. Particularly, the strong interaction between CoOx and DMSNs in 3Co-DMSNs-f plays an important effect on the stability of the catalyst. The molar ratios of Co2+/Co3+ species are presented in the XPS peak fitting results. With the same cobalt content of ∼1.7%, the 3Co-DMSNs-f sample synthesized by grafting method exhibits a much higher Co2+/Co3+ molar ratio than the 1.7%Co/DMSNs prepared by impregnation method. The Co2+/Co3+ ratio of 10%Co/DMSNs is 6.37, significantly higher than that of 1.7%Co/DMSNs. For the supported catalysts, a relatively high loading of active metals results in the formation of tiny CoOx clusters or nanoparticles and it seems to be beneficial to increasing surface content of Co2+ species. 3Co-DMSNs-f and 10%Co/DMSNs catalysts show superior catalytic performance in all the catalysts, suggesting that the Co2+ species are the active sites for toluene oxidation. Furthermore, the used catalysts were also characterized by XPS and an obvious difference in Co2+/Co3+ ratio between fresh and used catalysts is observed. For the 3Co-DMSNs-f catalyst, it shows a slight increase in the Co2+/Co3+ ratio after toluene oxidation. By comparison, an apparent decrease appears after reaction for the 10%Co/DMSNs. The H2-TPR and XPS results imply that CoOx species have a strong metal-support interaction in the 3Co-DMSNs-f catalyst. Thus, it possesses good structure stability and the CoOx species are not easy to be reduced into metallic state during toluene oxidation. The interaction between CoOx species and DMSNs is not strong enough, especially in the process of toluene oxidation over the Co/DMSNs. As a result, a part of the Co2+ species are oxidized and transformed into Co3+ species during reaction. The coordination geometry of cobalt-containing DMSNs catalysts was obtained using UV-vis spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. S3, the spectra exhibit three absorption bands located at around 524, 589 and 648 nm. These bands are the 4A2(F)→4T1(P) transition of Co2+ ions in tetrahedral geometry [40]. The XPS and H2-TPR results also show that cobalt mainly exists in the Co2+ oxidation state for the Co-DMSNs-f catalysts. However, a shoulder peak between 700 and 800 nm appears in the Co/DMSNs samples which correspond to the octahedral-coordinated Co2+, indicating the formation of polymeric CoOx species. Thus, UV-vis results demonstrate that Co2+ species in tetrahedral coordination are dominant in the Co-DMSNs-f catalysts. The geometric forms of CoOx species in the Co/DMSNs are diverse and the impregnation method easily causes the aggregation of CoOx species. 3.2 Characterization of the Pd-Co-containing DMSNs catalysts Fig. 7 presents the SEM and TEM images of Pd-Co-containing DMSNs catalysts. It can be clearly seen from Fig. 7(a–c) that the well-ordered dendritic mesoporous nanospheres structure is maintained for all samples. The spherical particles are uniform and exhibit a diameter of ∼280 nm. As shown in Fig. 7(d–i), a center-radial pore structure is observed for the Pd-Co-DMSNs samples and the Pd and Co atoms are highly dispersed on the pore surface of catalysts. As the HR-TEM images shown in Fig. 9(g–i), the lattice spacing of ∼0.227 nm attributes to the Pd (111) crystal plane [21]. However, lattice spacing at ∼0.23 nm can also be attributes to the Co3O4 (111) crystal planes. Combined with the XRD results, these nanoparticles are due to the Pd species and the TEM images reveals that the mean particle size of Pd is about 3,4 nm in the samples. A type IV sorption isotherm with H3 hysteresis loop is observed for all the Pd-Co-DMSNs catalysts (Fig. S4a), suggesting the existence of uniform mesopores [21]. The pore size distribution curves (Fig. S4b) show that the pore sizes of Pd-Co-DMSNs catalysts are mainly distributed between 5 and 60 nm and three distribution peaks appear at 25, 38 and 50 nm. The textural parameters of representative 2%Pd-Co-containing DMSNs are summarized in Table 2 . Generally, the introduction of Pd species shows no remarkable effect on the extural properties of the catalysts with low cobalt content, but the surface area and pore volume of 2%Pd-S10% catalyst decrease obviously. The introduction of Pd species may lead to local surface reconstruction in the site of active CoOx species. As a result, it has major influence on the textural properties of 2%Pd10%Co/DMSNs. Fig. 8 shows the XRD patterns of Pd-Co-DMSNs catalysts with different Pd loadings and different preparation methods. No significant diffractions are detected for 2%Pd-3 mM sample, indicating Pd atoms are highly dispersed on the catalyst surface. The diffractions due to spinel Co3O4 are weakened and new diffractions due to CoO appear in the 2%Pd-S10% sample. Pd-modification may result in the transformation of Co3O4 into CoO nanoparticles. The XPS results also show a very low Pd° content. Therefore, it should generate an interaction between Pd and Co3O4 species via the reaction of Pd0 + Co3+ → Pd2+ + Co2+. For the 2%Pd-S1.7% sample, a small peak due to Co3O4 species also transforms into CoO peaks in 1.7%Co/DMSNs after Pd addition. However the peaks related to the CoO species decrease and the obvious diffraction peaks assigned to Pd species appear with increasing Pd loading. It indicates that high Pd loading leads to the localized Pd aggregation. The H2-TPR was employed to investigate the reducibility of Pd-Co-DMSNs catalysts and the results are shown in Fig. 9 (a). The peaks observed at ∼200 °C and 300–400 °C can be attributed to the reduction of PdO to Pd0 and Co3+→Co2+→Co0, respectively [43]. Obviously, it generates an interaction between Pd and CoOx species and then influences the reducibility of catalysts. For the 2%Pd1.7%Co/DMSNs sample, no obvious reduction peak of PdO to Pd0 is observed, suggesting that the Pd species are mainly existed in the form of Pd metal. Besides, the reduction peaks of CoOx species are shifted to low temperature after the addition of Pd, suggesting that Pd-modification promotes the reduction of CoOx species. By comparison, 2%Pd10%Co/DMSNs and 2%Pd3Co-DMSNs-f samples show the reduction peaks assigned to PdO species and the CoOx species show a higher reduction temperature. The amounts of H2 consumption over Pd-Co-DMSNs samples were listed in Table 2. The H2 consumption of 2%Pd-3 mM and 2%Pd-S1.7% samples increases significantly via Pd-modification. As for the 2%Pd-S10% sample, the amount of H2 consumption is reduced actually. These results demonstrate that the Pd-modification should have an important effect on the surface oxygen species and the interaction between the CoOx and support. O2-TPD was also performed and the results are shown in Fig. 9(b). Generally, the analytical peaks below 600 °C are attributed to the desorption of surface chemically adsorbed oxygen (O2 −, O2 2− or O−) species [44]. The loading of Pd increases the amount of adsorbed oxygen species specially in the mid-temperature range for the 2%Pd1.7%Co/DMSNs, thereby improving the oxygen activation capacity of the catalyst [45]. Surface composition and element chemical state of the 2%Pd-Co-DMSNs catalysts were determined by the XPS technique. Fig. 10 illustrates the Pd 3d and Co 2p XPS spectra. As for the Pd 3d XPS spectra (Fig. 10a), the peaks at 335.6 and 340.9 eV are attributed to the surface Pd0 species, while the peaks at 337.1 and 342 eV are attributed to the surface Pd2+ species [46–48]. The Pd0/(Pd0+Pd2+) molar ratio of the samples are in the order of 0.88 (2%Pd-S1.7%) > 0.74 (2%Pd-3 mM) > 0.37 (2%Pd-S10%), which is in line with the catalytic activity. This also suggests that Pd0 species can markedly promote the low temperature performance of catalysts. Pd0 species are identified as the active center for catalytic oxidation of toluene into H2O and CO2 [49,50]. After the introduction of Pd species, the Co2+/Co3+ ratio basically remains unchanged for the 2%Pd1.7%Co/DMSNs, but shows an obvious drop for other catalysts. It suggests that there is an interaction between Pd and CoOx species and a part of the Co2+ species are oxidized to Co3+ species. 3.3 Catalytic performance for toluene oxidation 3.3.1 Comparison of the catalytic performance of Co-DMSNs-f and Co/DMSNs catalysts The catalytic performance of catalysts prepared by different synthesis methods for toluene oxidation was evaluated in a fixed-bed quartz reactor. Fig. 11 displays the results of toluene conversion as a function of reaction temperature over the Co-DMSNs-f catalysts and the typical Co/DMSNs catalysts. It can be seen that all the Co-containing catalysts show a positive effect on the toluene conversion compared with pure DMSNs support. Firstly, the toluene conversions of all the catalysts are strongly dependent on the reaction temperature and it causes a steep rise in toluene conversion. It is convenient to compare the catalytic activities of catalysts using the reaction temperatures T10, T50 and T90, corresponding to toluene conversion of 10%, 50% and 90%, respectively, as summarized in Table 3 . The lowest T90 of Co-DMSNs-f catalysts reaches nearly 280 °C. Besides, the catalytic activity is also closely related to the Co concentration for Co-DMSNs-f catalysts. A marked increase in the toluene conversion is observed when the Co concentration gradually increases from 0.5 to 3 mM at the same reaction temperature. But further increase of Co concentration from 3 to 10 mM results in a drop in activity. The 3Co-DMSNs-f catalyst shows the optimum performance, i.e., T50 and T90 are 248 and 280 °C, respectively. The XPS results show that Co2+/Co3+ molar ratio can reach up to 4.8 for the 3Co-DMSNs-f catalyst, suggesting that the Co2+ species are the main active sites. However, excessive Co concentration does not lead to a further increase in toluene conversion. This negative effect on the activity is likely due to the decrease in actual Co content of the catalysts. Furthermore, the synthesis method also plays a very important role in the catalytic activity. The controlled grafting process on the basis of functionalized mesoporous DMSNs favors the formation of highly dispersed Co2+ species and enhances the interaction with the silica support through the strong Co-O-Si bonds. For comparison, the catalytic performance of corresponding supported cobalt oxide catalysts (Co/DMSNs) prepared by the impregnation method was evaluated. The 1.7%Co/DMSNs sample containing the same Co content as 3Co-DMSNs-f shows lower activity. The T50 rises by 34 to 282 °C accordingly. Generally, silica supports usually trigger the formation of polymeric and crystalline metal oxides even at relatively low metal loading than other common supports [51]. The XRD results indeed show the appearance of crystalline CoOx species for the 1.7%Co/DMSNs sample. Actually, various CoOx species coexist and mainly present a high valence state of Co3+ in this supported catalyst. With respect to 10%Co/DMSNs sample, a uniform dispersion of CoOx nanoparticles are formed and mainly exists as the +2 valence state. The Co2+/Co3+ molar ratio can exceed 6.3, and it is suitable for the redox cycle and the total oxidation of toluene. For the 30%Co/DMSNs sample, however, excessive Co intrusion cannot be fully dispersed on the DMSNs support. A large amount of crystalline Co3O4 is formed in the pore of DMSNs, leading to the significant drop in the surface area and pore volume. In general, the mesoporous DMSNs materials with unique central-radial pore structures are a superior support for preparing supported catalysts. The large pore entrance is beneficial to the dispersity and accessibility of active sites in the internal surface. The highly dispersed Co2+ species are conducive to the toluene oxidation. The catalysts synthesized by grafting method contribute to the formation of highly dispersed Co2+ species and show strong interaction between Co2+ species and silica. It is worth noting that the Co2+ species can be maintained during the reaction over the Co-DMSNs-f. The XPS results show that Co2+/Co3+ molar ratio even increases slightly after the reaction as shown in Fig. 6. Conversely, the fresh catalysts synthesized by impregnation method show a relatively low Co2+/Co3+ molar ratio. The 10%Co/DMSNs sample has a high Co2+/Co3+ molar ratio, but shows an obvious drop after reaction. It may be due that CoOx species are easy to be oxidized to high valence state because of the weak interaction with silica support. It is not conducive to the catalytic oxidation of toluene. 3.3.2 Effect of toluene concentration, space velocity and water vapor The toluene removal efficacy at different toluene concentration is important in practical application. As shown in Fig. S5, the catalytic performance test was carried out under various toluene concentration in the feed gas over 3Co-DMSNs-f and 10%Co/DMSNs catalysts. The results show that the decrease in toluene concentration can enhance the catalytic performance obviously. For the 3Co-DMSNs-f catalyst, the T90 can drop from 360 to 280 °C when the toluene concentration decreases from 500 to 50 ppm, showing the good catalytic performance for the oxidation of low concentrations of toluene. The T90 of 10%Co/DMSNs only drop from 353 to 300 °C when the toluene concentration decreases from 500 to 50 ppm. Accordingly, the effect of space velocity (SV) on toluene oxidation over the 3Co-DMSNs-f catalyst was investigated. As shown in Fig. S6, toluene conversion drops evidently when SV increases from 15,000 to 60,000 ml∙g−1∙h−1, due to the shortening of contact time. The T90 is at about 340 °C as the SV reaches up to 60,000 ml∙g−1∙h−1. To examine the catalytic stability, toluene conversion within 24 h of on-stream reaction over 3Co-DMSNs-f and 10%Co/DMSNs catalysts were further evaluated (Fig. S7). It can be seen that both of the catalysts show no significant loss in activity. Generally, the catalytic activity for toluene oxidation is negatively affected by water vapor in the feed steam [17,52]. Therefore, the effect of water vapor on activity was investigated during the reaction stability testing. The introduction of water vapor shows obviously different effects on the performance of 3Co-DMSNs-f and 10%Co/DMSNs catalysts as shown in Fig. 12 . When 1.0 vol% water vapor is introduced to the feedstock, it is observed that the toluene conversion decreases from ca. 65 to 46% at 260 °C. The toluene conversion basically restores to the original level (ca. 61%) when water vapor is cut off. The activity decline in the presence of water vapor is due to the fierce competitive adsorption of water and toluene. The water vapor gives rise to a continuous negative effect on catalytic performance over 10%Co/DMSNs catalyst. By contrast, there is maximum ca. 30% loss in initial toluene conversion over 3Co-DMSNs-f catalyst when 1.0 vol% water vapor was introduced, but the toluene conversion shows a gradual tendency to recover. After water vapor was completely cut off, the toluene conversion can be restored to the original level prior to the steam addition. At the initial stage of introducing water vapor, it shows an obvious negative effect on toluene oxidation over the 3Co-DMSNs-f. This is due that the water molecules are rapidly adsorbed on the active sites. And then the H2O may further be involved in the activation of O2. It has been reported that O2 and H2O can be activated by formation of hydroperoxyl species via the H-transfer reactions in the presence of water vapor [46]. As a result, the presence of H2O exhibits a reversible negative effect on catalytic activity. 3.3.3 Effect of Pd component The supported noble metal catalysts especially Pd-based catalysts show extremely high catalytic activity for toluene oxidation. Herein, the Co-containing DNSNs samples are further used as support of catalysts and the effect of Pd component on the performance of toluene oxidation is investigated. Fig. 13 shows the catalytic activity of Pd-modified Co-DMSNs-f and Co/DMSNs catalysts. The T10, T50 and T90 temperatures are also summarized in Table 3. Obviously, all the Pd-modified catalysts perform much better activity than the catalysts without Pd. The loading of Pd can enhance the catalytic performance of Co-containing DMSNs samples. However, it can be clearly seen that Pd component shows a very different effect on the Co-containing DMSNs samples with different preparation method. The T50 and T90 of 2%Pd1.7%Co/DMSNs sample reduce by ca 122 and 107 °C compared to the 1.7%Co/DMSNs sample, and reach as low as 160 and 193 °C, respectively. In contrast, both T50 and T90 reduce by less than 60 °C for the Pd-modified 3Co-DMSNs-f or 10%Co/DMSNs catalysts. For the active Pd-CoOx catalysts, both Pd and CoOx are the active components. The interaction between Pd and CoOx species can influence the reactive sites especially at the Pd-CoOx interface. It may be beneficial to the generation of oxygen vacancies or toluene adsorption sites. The adsorption and activation of toluene should be the key influencing factor. There is a strong interaction between CoOx species and DNSNs support for the Co-DMSNs-f by grafting method. Addition of Pd weakens this interaction and leads to the oxidation of Co2+ into Co3+ species. For the 1.7%Co/DMSNs prepared by impregnation method, an interaction between Pd and CoOx species is generated via the reaction of Pd0 + Co3+ → Pd2+ + Co2+ partially. It leads to a rise in Co2+/Co3+ molar ratio after addition of Pd, but the Pd0 species are still the majority since the proportion of Pd0 remains at as high as 88%. The interaction between Pd0 and Co2+ species generates the synergistic effect in the processes of oxygen activation and toluene adsorption. Furthermore, the effect of Pd loading on the 1.7%Co/DMSNs sample was further investigated and the results are shown in Fig. 13(b). The increase in Pd loading from 0.5 to 3 wt% results in a sharp rise in activity. The T90 drops from original 300 °C for 1.7%Co/DMSNs to only 150 °C for 3%Pd1.7%Co/DMSNs. Therefore, the loading of Pd can markedly promote the performance for toluene combustion. 4 Conclusions The Co-DMSNs-f and Co/DMSNs catalysts were synthesized via grafting and impregnation method, respectively, and further modified by Pd component. The dendritic mesoporous structure can promote the dispersion of Co and Pd species and the transportation of reactants and products in the pore for toluene oxidation reaction. The controlled grafting process favors the formation of highly dispersed Co2+ species and enhances its interaction with silica support. With the same Co loading, the catalysts prepared by grafting method show better catalytic activity and H2O tolerant stability in toluene oxidation than the catalysts synthesized by impregnation method. The loading of Pd can enhance the catalytic performance of all the Co-containing DMSNs catalysts, and Pt-modified 1.7%Co/DMSNs catalyst shows better low-temperature activity. The supported 1.7%Co/DMSNs catalyst is more beneficial to the interaction between Pd0 and Co2+ species than the 3Co-DMSNs-f sample, and thus generates the synergistic effect in the processes of oxygen activation and toluene adsorption. It is concluded that the excellent catalytic performance of catalysts is related to the dominant Pd0 and Co2+ species, synergy between Pd0 and Co2+ components, moderate metal-support interaction and special structure of support. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic oxidation is an effective way for toluene-bearing VOCs removal. A series of Co-grafted dendritic mesoporous silica nanospheres (Co-DMSNs-f) were synthesized by the controlled grafting method. The catalysts show superior micro-structure, high dispersion of CoOx species and proper metal-support interaction. For comparison, corresponding DMSNs-supported CoOx samples were prepared by impregnation method. Co-grafted DMSNs samples yield better structure stability. For the Co-grafted DMSNs, moisture is involved in the activation of O2 and exhibits a short and reversible negative effect on catalytic activity. The influence of Pd-modification on the Co-containing catalysts was also investigated and the introduction of Pd can markedly enhance the catalytic performance. The supported catalysts generate proper CoOx-SiO2 and Pd-CoOx interactions. The Pd-CoOx interface can further influence the synergistic effect in oxygen activation and toluene adsorption. The tunable CoOx-support and Pd-CoOx interactions play an important role in the toluene oxidation.
coredata.dc:title: Dendritic mesoporous silica nanosphere supported highly dispersed Pd-CoOx catalysts for catalytic oxidation of toluene
